title: Scenario: The Hotel
reading_greek:
DIALOGUE
- Γεια σας. Έχω κράτηση. (Hello. I have a reservation.)
- Το όνομά σας; (Your name?)
- Justin. (Justin.)
- Ορίστε το κλειδί. (Here is the key.)
- Ευχαριστώ. Πού είναι το ασανσέρ; (Thanks. Where is the elevator?)
- Εκεί, δεξιά. (There, right.)
- Πού είναι το πρωινό; (Where is breakfast?)
- Στο μπαρ. (At the bar.)

KEY VOCAB
- Κράτηση (Reservation)
- Κλειδί (Key)
- Δωμάτιο (Room)
- Ασανσέρ (Elevator)
- Πρωινό (Breakfast)
- Δεξιά (Right) / Αριστερά (Left)
reading_english:
SCENARIO: CHECKING IN

1. I HAVE (Exo): The most useful verb.
   - Exo kratisi (I have a reservation).
   - Exo provlima (I have a problem).

2. WHERE IS (Pou einai): 
   - Pou einai to asanser? (Where is the elevator?)
   - Pou einai to domatio? (Where is the room?)

3. PREPOSITIONS (Se + To = Sto):
   - 'Sto bar' (At the bar).
   - 'Sto domatio' (In the room).
audio_script:
You arrive at your hotel in Athens. Time to check in.

Walk to the reception and say confidently: 'Exo kratisi' (I have a reservation). 

The receptionist will give you 'To kleidi' (The key).

Now, you need to find your way. Use 'Pou einai...?'.
- Pou einai to asanser? (Where is the elevator?)
- Pou einai to domatio mou? (Where is my room?)

Directions:
- Dexia (Right).
- Aristera (Left).
- Ekei (There).

quiz_questions.question: How do you say 'I have a reservation'?
The receptionist says 'Oriste'. What does it mean?
options: Here you go / Here it is.
quiz_questions.explanation: Oriste is used when handing something over.
